title: AB 1228
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to support foster care agencies by providing information on admissions requirements and financial aid to California's higher education institutions. They also urge the University of California and California State University to consider using admissions-by-exemption to help homeless and foster youth transition into four-year public colleges. Section 76010 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth at California Community Colleges. This includes giving first priority for year-round housing at no extra cost during academic breaks and next priority for housing open for the most days in the year. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is required to develop a plan to ensure housing resources for current and former homeless youth and foster youth between academic terms. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years old verified as homeless within the past 24 months by specific entities. A financial aid administrator. A student verified as a former homeless youth retains that status for six years from admission. Section 90001.5 of the Education Code is amended. Section 90001.5 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing at California State University campuses, with no extra cost during breaks, and year-round residence options. Each California State University campus is required to develop a plan to provide housing resources for current and former homeless youth and foster youth, ensuring access during academic breaks. Homeless youth are defined as students under 25 who have been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by specific entities. A financial aid administrator is mentioned in relation to former homeless youth, who retain their status for six years from admission. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing at University of California campuses, providing them with stable housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The University of California campuses are requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth have access to housing resources during academic breaks. Homeless youth are defined as students under 25 years old who have been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. A financial aid administrator can verify a student as a former homeless youth, and this status is retained for six years. The University of California is exempt from this section unless the Regents make it applicable.
